keyTakeAways: Christopher Moynihan, a former participant in the January 6 Capitol attack, was arrested on a charge of making a terroristic threat against Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries.
Moynihan previously served nearly two years in prison for obstructing an official proceeding and disorderly conduct during the Capitol attack.
President Donald Trump pardoned Moynihan earlier in 2025 as part of a broader pardon of January 6 defendants.
Moynihan reportedly threatened to kill Jeffries in a text message stating, 'I will kill him for the future,' and expressed intent to eliminate him due to political opposition.
A New York judge ruled that Moynihan remains in prison pending a trial on the terroristic threat charge, with no attorneys listed and no known family contact established.
Law enforcement has expressed concern over rising threats against public officials, especially following high-profile assassinations like that of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.

Moynihan's prior history includes opioid addiction and petty larceny, which his attorneys cited as contributing factors to his criminal behavior, and he was recommended for mental health and substance abuse treatment.
The case highlights tensions between executive pardoning power and public safety, especially regarding political threats following large-scale acts of civil unrest.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A man convicted of participating in the January 6, 2021 Capitol attack, Christopher Moynihan, was arrested on a charge of threatening to kill Democratic House Minority Leader Hakeem Jeffries. Despite being pardoned by President Donald Trump earlier in 2025, Moynihan faces a new terroristic threat charge, reportedly stemming from a text message in which he stated he would kill Jeffries 'for the future.' The case highlights ongoing concerns about political violence, especially after high-profile assassinations like that of Charlie Kirk. Moynihan has a history of substance abuse and prior convictions, and while he was recommended for mental health and addiction treatment during his original sentencing, he remains in prison pending trial on the new charge. The incident underscores tensions between executive pardoning power and public safety, especially regarding threats against elected officials.
title: Pardoned Capitol rioter arrested on charge that he threatened to kill Hakeem Jeffries
